summary: This document is an email chain from August 13-14, 2019, between federal prosecutors discussing evidence and legal strategy in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The emails focus on venue issues for trafficking offenses, evidence related to properties in Florida and the Virgin Islands, and the interplay between potential government forfeiture actions and impending civil lawsuits from victims under a new New York State law.

events.title: Discussion of Evidence and Venue
events.description: Prosecutors discuss the evidence linking trafficking offenses to Epstein's Florida property and the lack of evidence for offenses at the Virgin Islands property. They note that Florida victims were identified from a previous investigation and were called from New York, which could establish venue.

events.title: New York State Look-Back Law Takes Effect
events.description: Multiple attorneys plan to file civil lawsuits on behalf of clients starting this date, when a New York State law reopens the statute of limitations for sex crimes. The prosecutors discuss how a government forfeiture action might affect these civil claims.

events.title: Request for Forfeiture Strategy
events.description: A prosecutor requests a summary of forfeiture options regarding Epstein's properties in New York, Florida, and the Virgin Islands by the morning of August 15, 2019, and expresses a desire for a 'cognizable theory' to pursue them.

keyFacts: Prosecutors state that the only trafficking offenses with evidence involving Epstein's Florida property are those linked to victims identified in the original Florida investigation.
Prosecutors acknowledge they have no present evidence of trafficking offenses involving the Virgin Islands property, pending search warrant results.
A new New York State 'look-back' law reopening the statute of limitations for sex crimes was set to take effect on August 14, 2019, triggering planned civil lawsuits from victims.
Prosecutors were actively developing a legal theory to pursue forfeiture of Epstein's residences in New York, Florida, and the Virgin Islands.
The email chain reveals internal coordination and strategic planning among federal prosecutors shortly after Epstein's arrest, focusing on evidence limitations and legal procedures.
